ai-mn145:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn145:1.3_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Puṇṇa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
ai-mn145:1.3_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,
ai-mn145:2.1_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-mn145:2.2_0: “Well then, Puṇṇa, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn145:3.1_0: “Puṇṇa, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn145:3.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-mn145:3.4_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-mn145:3.5_0: There are sounds known by the ear ...
ai-mn145:3.9_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn145:3.10_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-mn145:3.12_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-mn145:4.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

ai-mn145:4.4_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.

ai-mn145:5.1_0: Puṇṇa, now that I’ve given you this brief advice, what country will you live in?”
ai-mn145:5.2_0: “Sir, there’s a country named Sunāparanta. I shall live there.”
ai-mn145:5.3_0: “The people of Puṇṇaka, are very clay,
ai-mn145:5.5_0: If they abuse and insult you, what will you think of them?”
ai-mn145:5.6_0: “If they abuse and insult me, I will think:
ai-mn145:5.7_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t hit me with their fists.’
ai-mn145:5.8_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-mn145:5.9_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-mn145:5.10_0: “But if they do hit you with their fists, what will you think of them then?”
ai-mn145:5.11_0: “If they hit me with their fists, I’ll think:
ai-mn145:5.12_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t throw stones at me.’
ai-mn145:5.13_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-mn145:5.14_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-mn145:5.15_0: “But if they do throw stones at you, what will you think of them then?”
ai-mn145:5.16_0: “If they throw stones at me, I’ll think:
ai-mn145:5.17_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t hit me with a stick.’
ai-mn145:5.18_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-mn145:5.19_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-mn145:5.20_0: “But if they do beat you with a club, what will you think of them then?”
ai-mn145:5.21_0: “If they beat me with a club, I’ll think:
ai-mn145:5.22_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t stab me with a knife.’
ai-mn145:5.23_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-mn145:5.24_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-mn145:5.25_0: “But if they do stab you with a knife, what will you think of them then?”
ai-mn145:5.26_0: “If they stab me with a knife, I’ll think:
ai-mn145:5.27_0: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they take my life with a sharp knife.’
ai-mn145:5.28_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-mn145:5.29_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-mn145:5.30_0: “But if they do take your life with a sharp knife, what will you think of them then?”
ai-mn145:5.31_0: “If they take my life with a sharp knife, I’ll think:
ai-mn145:5.32_0: ‘There are disciples of the Buddha who looked for someone to assist with slitting their wrists because they were horrified, repelled, and disgusted with the body and with life.
ai-mn145:5.32_1: And I have found this without looking!’
ai-mn145:5.33_0: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
ai-mn145:5.34_0: That’s why he’ll be reborn there!”
ai-mn145:6.2_0: Having such self-control and peacefulness, you will be quite capable of living in Sunāparanta.
ai-mn145:6.3_0: Please, Puṇṇa, go at your convenience.”
ai-mn145:7.1_0: And then Puṇṇa welcomed and agreed with the Buddha’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sunāparanta.
ai-mn145:7.2_0: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sunāparanta,
ai-mn145:7.3_0: where he stayed in a country of Sumedhā.
ai-mn145:7.4_0: Then Puṇṇa Jayasena turned around five hundred lay followers within the Rains Retreat. In that very life he precincts, dwelt in the known by the name of Saccaka.
ai-mn145:7.5_0: Then after some time Venerable Puṇṇa became fully extinguished.
ai-mn145:8.1_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-mn145:8.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn145:8.2_0: “Sir, the gentleman named Puṇṇa, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.
ai-mn145:8.3_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ai-mn145:8.4_0: “Mendicants, Puṇṇa was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ai-mn145:8.6_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn145:8.7_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn145:8.8_0: The third section on the Discourse with Puṇṇa is finished.
